title: Foxtel and NBCUniversal close to expanded TV and streaming deal
text:
"Foxtel is close to an agreement with NBCU and looking forward to making an announcement in the coming weeks," a Foxtel spokesman said.

NBCU declined to comment.

The negotiations are believed to have taken so long because of Foxtel's efforts to reduce its programming costs while getting a hold of streaming rights for a new drama and entertainment streaming service, known internally as Project Ares.

With revenue under pressure, Foxtel has been looking to find savings in its $1.6 billion worth of programming costs – split 50-50 between sport and other content.

In August, Foxtel locked down a new long-term agreement with BBC, including drama such as Taboo, The Night Manager and Call the Midwife, as well as documentary series such as Planet Earth and Blue Planet.

It's believed Foxtel will now turn its attention to trying to nail down new deals with Discovery, Viacom and Turner.

The pay TV provider, which is 65 per cent owned by News Corp and 35 per cent owned by Telstra, wants to build its catch-up library as it works to try and get Project Ares over the line. Sources said it needed these programming deals locked in before it could move forward on the new streaming service.

Foxtel needs to balance its costs with the need to have large amounts of content in order to justify charging its subscribers the amount it does – its residential average revenue per user from satellite and cable customers is $78 per month.

A new streaming service will not have the Foxtel name and will be aimed at customers who don't have cable and satellite TV, in the same vein as its sports streaming service Kayo. However, the entertainment streaming market is intensely competitive and Foxtel faces a tough fight against the dominant players, Netflix and Stan, which is owned by Nine, publisher of the Financial Review, the imminent entry of global giants Disney and Apple, as well as a host of already launched players like Amazon Prime Video and 10 All Access.

Its streaming (over-the-top) customer base grew to 776,000 at June 30, including subscribers for Kayo and Foxtel Now, which replicates the broadcast service via streaming. News Corp will give updated numbers for Foxtel at its first quarter results in early November.

"What we do know from around the globe is that a lot of customers won’t just have one proposition, they’ll have multiple propositions in relation to OTT, so we do think that there is a large OTT market that exists already within Australia that we either are part of or can tap into going forward," News Corp chief financial officer Susan Panuccio said from the Bank of America Merrill Lynch 2019 media, communications and entertainment conference in September.
description: Foxtel and the US media giant, which is owned by Comcast, are almost ready to announce a new content deal, which includes shows such as The Office.
